title: Access Control & Specifiers
description: Comprehensive guide to Swift's access control system. Learn about private, fileprivate, internal, public, and open access levels with detailed use cases.

sections.title: Access Control Overview
sections.content:
Swift provides five access levels to control the visibility and accessibility of your code:

1. **open** - Most permissive (classes and class members only)
2. **public** - Accessible from any module
3. **internal** - Default, accessible within the same module
4. **fileprivate** - Accessible only within the same file
5. **private** - Most restrictive, accessible only within the same declaration

These levels help you create well-encapsulated APIs and maintain code organization.

Internal Access (Default)
sections.content:
**Internal** is the default access level in Swift.

- Accessible anywhere within the same module
- No access modifier needed (it's the default)
- Perfect for app-level code

```swift
class MyClass {  // Implicitly internal
    var property: String  // Implicitly internal
}
```

When building a framework or library, internal members are not accessible to clients. Use public or open for API surface.

sections.title: Public Access
Open Access
Access Control Rules
sections.content:
Important rules to remember:

1. **Subclassing**: A subclass cannot have higher access than its superclass
2. **Overriding**: Overriding methods cannot have lower access than the original
3. **Generics**: Access level of generic type is the minimum of the type and its constraints
4. **Extensions**: Extensions have the same access as the type they extend
5. **Protocols**: Protocol requirements must match the protocol's access level

**Best Practices**:
- Start with private, increase access only when needed
- Use internal for app code
- Use public/open for framework APIs
- Document your public API thoroughly

sections.title: Common Use Cases
sections.content:
**When to use each level**:

- **Private**: Internal state, helper methods, implementation details
- **Fileprivate**: Shared utilities in the same file
- **Internal**: Default for app code, module-internal APIs
- **Public**: Framework APIs that clients should use
- **Open**: Framework base classes meant for subclassing

**Example - Well-designed API**:
```swift
public class NetworkManager {
    public func fetchData() async throws -> Data { }
    internal func setupSession() { }  // Implementation detail
    private var session: URLSession  // Internal state
}
```
